metadata.sermon_start_end: Not long ago I attended a memorial event in a secular setting. The tributes and reminiscences went on for about an hour and a quarter. Most of them were very well done, but during the more self-indulgent ones I found my attention drifting. [...] He goes to prepare a place for us at his own unending banquet. May he confirm this truth in your hearts, today and for ever. Amen.
metadata.notes: Preached at St. John’s Church, Washington, CT, in 1998.

logos.analysis: The sermon follows an inductive structure, beginning with human experience (regret/longing) and moving toward the biblical solution. The logical architecture is built on the metaphor of 'running out'—of wine, of time, and of meaning. The preacher effectively connects the archaeological/cultural details of the stone jars to the theological concept of failed religious ritual. However, the transition between the personal ads/secular anecdotes and the exegesis of John 2 feels slightly elongated, delaying the primary argument. The logic is consistent: human effort is 'water' (colorless/joyless), while Christ’s provision is 'wine' (abundant/redemptive).
quotes: Water from them is used for the washing away of sin. It is used, but it doesn’t work.
The water in the story represents all our human attempts, and especially our religious attempts, to make things right.

And so when Jesus, at a wedding, poured out more good wine than anyone had ever seen, those who had eyes to see and ears to hear recognized that the future blessings of the heavenly kingdom had become present.
strengths: Strong use of the 'water vs. wine' antithesis to explain the failure of legalism.
Effective mathematical calculation of the wine's volume to emphasize the 'abundance' argument.
Clear connection between the Cana sign and the broader Johannine 'I Am' statements.
improvement_points: The introduction is disproportionately long compared to the exegetical core.
The logic regarding Jesus' 'rudeness' to Mary is a bit of a parenthetical detour that slows the main argument.
The conclusion jumps quickly from the Cana miracle to the Cross without a detailed logical bridge.
logos.specific_diagnosis: The Logos is functional and traceable, relying heavily on a central metaphor, but suffers from a slow-starting argumentative engine.

pathos.analysis: Pathos is the sermon's strongest suit. The preacher masterfully taps into universal existential anxieties: regret, the fear of 'is that all there is?', and the 'creeping chill' of aging. By using diverse cultural touchpoints—from Edith Piaf and T.S. Eliot to personal ads in the New York Review of Books—the preacher creates a high degree of emotional resonance. The imagery of the 'last slice of filet mignon' at a wedding that ended in divorce is a poignant, recognizable 'slice of life' that grounds the theological concept of human insufficiency in felt reality.
pathos.emotional_tone: Wistful and existential, transitioning into exuberant hope.
quotes: I do not believe there is any one within earshot today, however well defended, who does not recognize the creeping chill of that feeling — 'there should have been more to it all.'
Nowhere will you find a more comprehensive index of human longing [than the personal ads].
I want you to feel this in your inmost being. What has Jesus done? Twenty-one hundred glasses of the finest vintage for one little wedding party!
strengths: Exceptional use of 'human longing' as a bridge to the Gospel.
Vivid sensory details (the 'creeping chill', the 'tasteless' water).
Avoids sentimentality by using sharp, literary examples of disappointment.
improvement_points: The shift from the 'wistful' tone to the 'exuberant' tone in the final third is somewhat abrupt.
The use of the Dave Barry reference slightly undercuts the gravitas established by Eliot and Piaf.
The emotional appeal could be more specifically tied to the joy of the 'servants' who knew the source.
pathos.specific_diagnosis: High-level Pathos that successfully transforms an ancient miracle into a contemporary existential necessity.

ethos.analysis: The preacher establishes Ethos through a combination of intellectual competence (literary citations) and pastoral vulnerability. By admitting that his own mind wandered during a memorial service, he positions himself as a fellow traveler rather than a moral superior. He explicitly addresses his status as a guest preacher, which builds transparency and trust. He claims authority not from his '22 years of ministry' but from his role as a witness who asked the Lord for the 'Spirit and Word' for this specific congregation.
ethos.authenticity: High; the preacher admits to drifting attention and the pressure of guest preaching.
quotes: I began wondering what trivial anecdotes people would tell about me some day as though they revealed the inmost depths of my character.
As I prepared this sermon, I asked the Lord in prayer to give me his Spirit and his Word this morning so that my visit will be a visit not from myself, but from him.
I find myself nowadays preaching, more often than not, to congregations I do not know... I take this responsibility very seriously.
strengths: Honest admission of personal mortality and professional pressure.
Intellectual credibility established without appearing elitist.
improvement_points: The mention of 'means and mien' in the ad could have been used for a deeper self-reflection on the preacher's own status.
The 'independence from human ties' section regarding Jesus could have been balanced with more personal warmth toward the listeners.
The transition to the final 'Amen' feels a bit like a standard liturgical exit rather than a personal seal.
ethos.specific_diagnosis: Strong Ethos based on 'the good man speaking well' and a clear sense of accountability to the text and the audience.

rhetorical_balance_analysis.analysis: The sermon is heavily weighted toward Pathos, using existential longing as the primary vehicle for the message. Ethos supports this by making the preacher appear as a relatable, thoughtful observer of the human condition. Logos is present and provides a solid enough foundation (the water-pots/purification argument), but it serves the emotional narrative rather than driving the sermon. The balance is effective for a secularized or 'searching' congregation, as it meets them in their felt needs before offering the theological solution.
consequences_of_imbalance: Hearers seeking deep exegetical rigor might find the literary anecdotes a bit long-winded.
The emotional weight of the 'regret' section is so strong it risks overshadowing the 'joy' of the miracle.
The logical connection between 'regret' and 'purification jars' is clever but might be missed by those caught up in the emotional stories.
rhetorical_balance_analysis.recommendation_for_balance: Shorten the secular introduction by 15% and expand the exegetical explanation of why the 'sign' specifically points to the Cross to strengthen the Logos.

orthodoxy_logos.analysis: The sermon is doctrinally sound, emphasizing Christ's divinity, the insufficiency of works/ritual, and the abundance of grace.

orthopathy_pathos.analysis: The sermon successfully awakens a 'God-fearing longing' and a sense of relief in Christ's provision, moving from worldly regret to spiritual hope.

orthopraxy_ethos.analysis: The preacher models a life of prayer and serious vocational responsibility, though the sermon focuses more on 'being' and 'receiving' than specific 'doing'.

overall_picture.summary: This is a rhetorically sophisticated sermon that excels in connecting biblical narrative to the modern psyche. The preacher uses the 'Cana' story not just as a historical wonder, but as a diagnostic for the 'empty jars' of contemporary American life. The use of Pathos is masterful, utilizing high-culture references (Eliot, Piaf) and low-culture artifacts (personal ads) to create a sense of universal human need. While the Logos is clear, it is occasionally secondary to the evocative power of the illustrations. The Ethos is that of a seasoned, humble witness. The sermon is highly effective for an educated, perhaps slightly cynical or weary congregation, as it validates their 'regret' before offering the 'good wine' of the Gospel. It avoids the pitfall of being a mere lecture by maintaining a strong affective charge throughout.
strengths_top_3: Masterful use of existential 'longing' to create a need for the Gospel.
Brilliant metaphorical link between the purification jars and failed human efforts.
High degree of relatability and vulnerability in the preacher's persona.
improvement_points_top_3: The introduction is slightly over-developed, delaying the biblical text.
The transition from the 'regret' of the personal ad to the 'joy' of Cana could be more logically robust.
The conclusion relies on a rapid-fire list of 'I Am' statements that lacks the narrative depth of the earlier sections.
overall_picture.audience_analysis: Educated, middle-to-upper class 'seekers' or long-time churchgoers struggling with the 'emptiness' of modern success.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Tighten the opening anecdotes to reach the biblical text sooner.
Develop the 'servants' perspective more to provide a model for human response (Orthopraxy).
Ensure the 'joy' of the miracle is as palpably described as the 'chill' of regret.
overall_picture.conclusion: A strong, professional example of the 'New Homiletic' approach, where the experience of the text is prioritized. It scores a 7 overall because while it is excellent in Pathos, the Logos could be more tightly integrated into the opening movement. It is a model of how to use secular culture to serve the proclamation of the Word without compromising the core message of grace.
